paper_metadata.title: MAIN TEXT
paper_metadata.extraction_summary: Extracted genetic variant information for the TTR gene, including penetrance data.

patients.demographics: Patients from endemic foci of Portugal and Japan, predominantly male.
patients.phenotype: Early-onset amyloid neuropathy with high penetrance.

individual_records.phenotype_details: Early disease onset with marked autonomic dysfunction.
individual_records.evidence_sentence: Patients from the conventional endemic foci of Portugal and Japan exhibit textbook features of amyloid neuropathy, such as early disease onset ranging in age from the late 20s to early 40s; a high penetrance rate.

individual_records.phenotype_details: Loss of superficial sensation and atrioventricular conduction block.
individual_records.evidence_sentence: Marked autonomic dysfunction; loss of superficial sensation, including nociception and thermal sensation (i.e., sensory dissociation); atrioventricular conduction block requiring pacemaker implantation.

functional_data.summary: The Val30Met mutation leads to unstable TTR, resulting in amyloid fibril formation.

variants.segregation_data: Segregates with disease in families from endemic regions.
variants.evidence_level: Strong evidence based on clinical presentation and family studies.
variants.additional_notes: The Val30Met mutation is the most common mutation associated with ATTRv amyloidosis.
key_quotes: Over 130 mutations have been reported so far.
The Val30Met mutation has been considered the most common mutation.

tables_processed.table_caption: Clinical features of patients with TTR mutations.

extraction_metadata.notes: All relevant data for the TTR gene was successfully extracted.
